thread.title: World title shot driving Price’s rapid return
thread.title_full: World title shot driving Price’s rapid return

title: World title shot driving Price’s rapid return
text:
CLEARED: Doctors allow Toby Price to fly home to Australia 
That date marks the opening round of the FIM Cross Country Rallies World Championship in Abu Dhabi, running throughout the first week of April. 
It’s an event Price won last year, one of two wins and a second place he scored on his way to third in the overall season standings. 
But Price missed out on a maiden world championship by a handful of points after being forced to withdraw from one of the five rounds due to a niggling back injury. 
“We were leading the rally in Abu Dhabi and (on the) last day I aggravated it a little bit,” Price told foxsports.com.au before leaving for this year’s Dakar. 
“We had a week off between the first and second world championship round at Qatar. I did a lot of work in that week to try and band-aid myself up and get it sorted, but on the second day in Qatar it just flamed up again.” media_camera Price on his way to victory in Abu Dhabi last year. 
The withdrawal came with an eye to ensure his body was ready for the rigours of pursuing a second Dakar title. 
“For sure, I could’ve kept going and been in the top five and survived the event,” he said. 
“Or it could’ve caused more damage and then I would have to take another 12 months off to get ready — or band-aid myself up for Dakar, and you definitely don’t want to be doing that. 
“I think if I’d got a fourth or better at Qatar, that would’ve been a world championship for me (in 2016) as well. 
“It’s a little bit of a hard pill to swallow once you see how the rest of the year worked out, but things happen for a reason. I think we made the right choice.” media_camera Price after winning the final round of last year’s world championship in Morocco. 
Whether Price will be fit for duty remains to be seen but it would be a brave person to bet against him giving it a good crack. 
When Price broke three vertebrae in a race crash in April 2013 doctors were astonished the injuries had not rendered him a quadriplegic. Just five months later he was back on a motorbike. 
Back to back rounds again kick off the 2017 FIM Cross Country Rallies World Championship, with the Abu Dhabi Desert Challenge on April 1-7 followed a week later by the Sealine Cross-Country Rally in Qatar on April 16-21.
